passages.text: We revised up 3Q GDP from \(1.5\% - 7.5\%\) Profit margins and real wage growth have held up amidst rising tariffs and slowing job growth The Lisa Cook removal goes to court with an uncertain outcome Expect a 75k rise in August nonfarm payrolls and a \(4.3\%\) unemployment rate

After last week's Jackson Hole Symposium cemented expectations for a 25bps rate cut at the September FOMC meeting, the focus shifted back to the economic data. That data suggested growth was holding up this quarter and we raised our 3Q GDP forecast from \(1.5\%\) to \(2.5\%\) . The releases this week brought limited new insight into the labor market, though we will get a clearer picture next week with the release of the August employment report. We look for a 75k increase in total and private nonfarm employment, and a slight rise in the unemployment rate, from \(4.2\%\) to \(4.3\%\) . Although inflation and growth data don't scream out for a rate cut, at this stage it would likely require a significant positive employment surprise to stop the FOMC from moving forward, given their concern about the sharp recent deceleration in job growth.

Even with Jackson Hole behind us, Federal Reserve developments didn't stop, as President Trump made a "for cause" dismissal of Governor Lisa Cook on Monday night, following his call for her to resign last week. Cook immediately filed suit and an initial hearing in DC District Court was held today on the matter Friday. The court has asked for more written arguments to be submitted by Tuesday, though it is unclear when we should expect a decision.

Even if the court rules in favor of Cook, it is not certain that she would be allowed to return to her duties immediately while the government further appeals the case. For example, in the recent Trump v. Wilcox case, the Supreme Court ruled that removed members of the NLRB and MSPB should not be allowed to return to their duties while they continued to litigate against their dismissal. That case concerned whether for cause protections held at all at the NLRB and MSPB, but the same reasoning might be applied to this case.

If the president is successful in terminating Cook soon, then he might be able to install another Board member by next February, when the Board needs to approve the re- appointment of all District Bank presidents. In addition, the Board has the power to "To suspend or remove any officer or director of any Federal Reserve Bank" at any time as long as the cause is communicated in writing. While the president may

soon have a majority of governors who agree with at least some of his views on rate cutting, this does not necessarily imply that these same members- for example Governor Waller- would be inclined to break tradition and start mass dismissals of District Bank presidents.

One other issue that this case raises is the establishment of more recent precedent about the process for establishing cause in a "for cause" termination of a Fed governor. For cause dismissals are extremely rare, and they have never been applied to a Fed governor. The Federal Reserve Act does not specify what "for cause" means, though a common interpretation is inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance while in office. Once a clearer template is established for how the executive branch will determine a valid cause, it is possible that this administration, or future ones, might become more prone to using for cause dismissals.

We have been forecasting a 2H25 slowdown for some time, but while employment gains have already decelerated, the other activity data has surprised to the upside, and we now expect real GDP growth of \(2.5\%\) in 3Q, which is in fact an acceleration from the 1H average of \(1.25\%\) . That includes domestic final sales growth of \(2.3\%\) . This raises the question of whether the negative effects of tariffs on growth beyond the first half are not materializing, or whether they are simply set to appear later than we had anticipated. We have not changed our forecasts beyond 3Q, though we are likely to revisit this question following next week's employment report.
Figure 1: Pretax corporate profit margins, NIPAs Percent, sa. Profits are before income taxes but include tariff charges

A notable feature of the recent trajectory has been that corporate profits are still doing well despite limited pass- through of tariffs to consumer prices, and that real wage income is likewise doing considerably better than employment growth. Corporate profits before income taxes for 2Q, which were released this week, showed a surprising \(1.7\% q / q\) (not annualized) increase despite rising government tariff revenues. Moreover, profit margins for nonfinancial domestic corporate businesses didn't change quarter- on- quarter. They have com
pressed \(\sim 50\) bps from a year earlier, though are still at healthy levels (Figure 1).

Likewise, on a \(3\mathrm{m / 3m}\) basis nonfarm payroll growth has slowed to just \(0.5\%\) through July, and yet real wage income over the same period was \(2.3\%\) and nominal income \(4.4\%\) which has helped cushion any shock to consumer spending (Figure 2). Slowing job growth linked to a decline in labor demand should translate into a shorter workweek and lower wage growth, but to date the big job slowdown of the last few months has produced neither of these things.
Figure 2: Nominal wages and nonfarm payroll employment
Source: BEA, BLS, J.P. Morgan

The key data releases that shaped the latest update to the 3Q forecast were those for durable goods, consumption, trade, and inventories. On consumption, July's \(0.3\% \mathrm{m / m}\) increase was in fact in line with our forecasts, but our auto analysts now expect just a \(1\%\) fall in unit auto sales in August, which improves the chance we could see quicker gains for the rest of the quarter. Consequently, we've boosted our spending forecast to \(2.0\%\) from \(1.5\%\) , slightly faster than the \(1.6\%\) gain in 2Q.
Figure 3: All-industry capex expectations from regional Fed surveys
Source: District FR Banks, J.P. Morgan

Equipment investment gets a larger upgrade. Between the durable goods report and a widening capital goods trade balance real investment is now tracking close to a \(15\%\) gain, the same as the 1H pace, though given the volatility in some of this data we've tempered that and settled on a still very solid \(10\%\) forecast. Detailed trade data is not out until next week, but we wouldn't be surprised if it shows a renewed surge in

capital goods imports being driven by tech equipment linked to the AI boom. We also finished getting the regional Fed surveys this week, which showed a continued gradual recovery in firm capex intentions (Figure 3).

Speaking of AI, one notable feature of the revised 2Q GDP figures that were released this week was a large upward revision to IPP growth, revised from \(6.4\%\) to \(12.8\%\) , reflecting big upgrades to both software and R&D. Real software investment has risen \(22\%\) annualized in 1H after rising just \(4\%\) in 2024, which may reflect a lift from enterprise spending on generative AI products. Over the first half of this year we estimate that tech- linked capex on data center, power, and communication construction, equipment investment, and software contributed a sizable \(0.4 - 0.5\%\) to annualized GDP growth. That may understate the profits being captured by domestic semiconductor firms who are manufacturing overseas. If we exclude net exports, where the tech trade deficit in goods has ballooned, the contribution to growth is closer to \(1.2\%\) .

July core PCE inflation was in line with forecasts and will not have been surprising to anyone on the FOMC. Core inflation rose \(0.27\% \mathrm{m / m}\) and the over- year- ago pace rose to \(2.9\%\) , up from the recent \(2.6\%\) trough in April and still very much within the narrow range that has persisted since early last year. In other words, inflation appears sticky, with limited progress back toward the Fed's \(2\%\) target. While not all of this data was known at the time of the July FOMC meeting, it's no surprise that meeting minutes showed "many participants observed that overall inflation remained somewhat above" the \(2\%\) target.

In that meeting, "a couple" participants suggested that ex- tariff inflation was already close to target. One of these was likely Governor Waller, who re- iterated this point in a speech this week. While the speech was mostly about labor market risks, Waller noted that "underlying inflation continues to run close to the FOMC's 2 percent target" once tariff effects are taken out. That is based on recent Fed staff work to track tariff- linked inflation.

Perhaps a simpler illustration of this point is that core services inflation, which should be less immediately sensitive to tariffs than goods, rose \(3.5\%\) , which is only moderately higher than the roughly \(3\%\) pace that prevailed from the mid- 1990s to the Great Recession. In the 2010s it dipped further, though arguably to too low a level given core PCE routinely undershot the \(2\%\) target. In contrast, core goods inflation has accelerated to \(1.1\%\) , about \(1.5\%\) - pt stronger than the average in the couple decades preceding COVID.

Sources for all: ADP/Moody's Analytics, BEA, BLS, Census Bureau, Confed, Department of Labor, Federal Reserve Board, ISM, J.P. Morgan forecasts, NAHB, S&P, NFIB, NY Fed, Philadelphia Fed, S&P Global, Standard & Poor's, University of Michigan, Treasury

Tue Sep 2 9:45amS&amp;P Global manufacturing PMI (US final)Index, saJul 24Jul 25Aug 25Final Aug 25Composite49.649.853.353.0Output50.551.355.2ISM-weighted composite49.749.453.0Tue Sep 2 10:00amISM manufacturingSaMayJunJulAugOverall index48.549.048.049.0New orders47.646.447.1Production45.450.351.4Employment46.845.043.4Supplier deliveries56.154.249.3Inventories46.749.248.9Export orders40.146.346.1Imports39.947.447.6Prices69.469.764.8

We expect the August ISM manufacturing survey to inch up to 49.0 from 48.0 in July, while the final PMI manufacturing composite remains level at 53.0, compared to the flash print of 53.3. The PMI has portrayed a more optimistic outlook for the manufacturing sector since the beginning of the year, whereas the ISM index has declined repeatedly since January, apart from a brief increase in June. The regional Empire, Philadelphia, Kansas City, Dallas and Richmond Fed surveys released so far have improved through the month, with the average composite moving to 51.9 from 51.0 in the prior month.

The manufacturing PMI composite improved by 3.5 points in the flash reading vs. July, with all components contributing to the growth. The measures for output, new export orders, and backlogs of work reached their highest levels in three years, signaling a pickup in activity. While the July ISM print lacked improvement in the headline reading, the production index recovered from a cycle low of 44.0 in April to 51.4 in the latest report. Manufacturing IP has been little changed in recent months after strong readings earlier in the year, possibly partially driven by front- loading efforts by firms ahead of anticipated tariffs. However, the improving signals from the surveys suggest the series could pick up again in the coming months.

Price pressures continue to build in the sector, with the latest PMI input price metric partially erasing the moderation seen through July with a 2.5- point increase in August. The PPI index for intermediate demand materials and components for manufacturing has risen \(3.3\%\) oya, the highest in over three years, and this has also been reflected in the core goods PCE

deflator, which picked up to \(1.1\%\) oya in July compared to \(0.3\%\) in April. The employment index in the PMI report has been volatile since June, with the August print rising by over 4 points, even though in recent months the series has overestimated payroll growth in the industry, which has been contracting.
ISM manufacturing index and regional ISM-weighted composites Index, sa
PMI and ISM manufacturing employment and payroll employment
Source: S&P Global, ISM, BLS, J.P. Morgan

Tue Sep 2 10:00amConstruction spending %m/m, saAprMayJunJulNominal0.1-0.4-0.4-0.3Private-0.2-0.6-0.5-0.6Residential-0.4-0.6-0.7-0.9New residential-1.4-1.5-1.4-1.4Improvements1.30.70.5Nonresidential0.0-0.5-0.3-0.2Public1.10.00.10.4

We expect construction spending to continue contracting going into the second half of the year, with a \(0.3\% m / m\) fall in July, driven by a persistent decline in private residential construction. Single- family construction spending has been deteriorating as homebuilders cut starts and work through elevated inventories of homes amid muted demand. While declining prices and increased use of incentives could help prop up sales, high mortgage rates have been preventing any material uptick in buying activity. In contrast, the volatile multifamily component is set to contribute positively in July, as starts rose \(1.5\% m / m\) during the month.

After a weak start to the year, construction spending on home improvement picked up through 2Q. However, with retail sales for building materials falling by \(1\% m / m\) and a \(0.1\% m / m\) drop in employment across specialty residential trade contractors, home improvement could prove to be a drag on residential construction spending in July. Nonresidential construction spending is also set to fall \(0.2\% m / m\) in July, following a strong run earlier in the decade, as investments in semiconductor facilities were boosted by the CHIPS Act. Data center spending, however, continues to grow robustly, with a \(1.8\% m / m\) increase in June and a \(28\%\) rise over the last 12 months.
Main categories of construction spending, nominal spending
Source: Census Bureau, J.P. Morgan
North America Economic Research United States 29 August 2025
Private res. improvement spending vs. retail sales at building stores
Source: Census Bureau, J.P. Morgan
Private construction: computer mfg + data centers. vs other nonres
Source: Census Bureau, J.P. Morgan
Construction spending on data centers
Source: Census Bureau, J.P. Morgan

Wed Sep 3 10:00amJOLTSThousands, sa, unless notedAprMayJunJulJob openings7395771274377250Job openings rate (%)4.44.64.44.3Hires561554655204Hires rate (%)3.53.43.3Separations531352135060Separations rate (%)3.33.33.2Quits321532703142Quits rate (%)2.02.02.0Layoffs178916111604Layoffs rate (%)1.11.01.0
We expect job openings in July, as reported in JOLTS, to drop to 7.250mn from 7.437mn in June, leading to the job openings rate falling to \(4.3\%\) . Daily job openings reported by

Indeed inched down between the end of June and July, and the employment components on the small business optimism index also declined throughout the month, signaling a drop in job openings. The hires rate has stayed in a narrow range over the last year, though it did slip \(0.2\%\) - pt in the last couple months.

While the overall quits rate has been stable, the accommodation and food services sector has experienced a surge in quits, rising from a recent low of 3.7 in January to 4.9 in June. We recently hypothesized that this could result from increased enforcement of the administration's immigration policies; especially the termination of humanitarian parole programs such as CHNV, which may lead to increased turnover in select industries, although the evidence so far is mixed. Following the spike in separations among government workers at the beginning of the year, caused by DOGE- led efforts to reduce the workforce, the latest reading in this category shows a separation rate of \(1.2\%\) , the lowest since the summer of 2014.
Job openings rate Percent, sa
Quit rate Percent, sa
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan
Quit rate: leisure and hospitality Percent, sa
Total separations rate: Government percent, sa
Wed Sep 3Light vehicle sales Millions, saarMayJunJulLight trucks and autos15.615.316.4Domestics12.212.012.8Autos1.71.71.8Light trucks10.410.311.0Imports3.53.33.6

Our auto equity analysts expect light vehicle sales in July to inch down to 16.2mn saar from 16.4mn, based on preliminary data. This would continue to showcase resilient auto sales following the downturn observed in May and June, as the earlier front- loading ahead of April tariffs began to wane. The team recently remarked that the expiration of US federal tax credits on electric vehicles could be contributing to growing demand, as affirmed by increased BEV penetration through July, along with an improved supply of luxury brands that had partially halted shipments since April. Our auto team will revisit its forecast next week as more data becomes available.
Thu Sep 4 8:15amADP employmentChange from month ago, 000s, saMayJunJulADP private payrolls29-23104BLS private payroll69383

The ADP reading of private sector employment had a stark upturn in July rising by 104k, following soft readings since the beginning of the year, including a negative print in June. The July ADP print marked improving payrolls across all sectors, apart from education and health services, which was the main source of growth in the BLS measure of private payroll growth. In a speech on August 28, Fed governor Waller noted that weekly ADP data obtained by the Fed was pointing to renewed weakness in job growth, so August could revert to a weaker print again. Note though that the average absolute error between first prints of ADP and BLS over the last 12 months is 76k.
Private sector employment m/m changes, as revised 000s, sa
Source: ADP, BLS, J.P. Morgan

Thu Sep 4 8:30amInternational tradeAprMayJunBalance(BOP basis)-60.3-71.7-60.2Services26.025.625.7Goods-86.3-97.3-85.9Exports (%m/m)3.4-4.1-0.5Services2.2-0.6-0.2Goods4.0-5.9-0.7Imports (%m/m)-16.3-0.1-3.7Services0.5-0.3-0.3Goods-19.9-0.1-4.5

We anticipate the goods and services trade deficit to widen to \(79.4 billion in June from\) 60.2 billion in May, based on already released figures on goods trade. The final trade print would help detangle the impact of any potential surge in gold imports, which are excluded from GDP accounting, from the large \(25\%\) m/m jump in industrial supply goods, causing an outsized widening of the goods trade balance through July. After a weak start to the year, household spending on services in the PCE data has picked up slightly, which could signal an uptick in services imports that have been in contractionary territory over the past two months. Services exports remain weak, weighed down by a lack of foreign demand for tourism and the absence of any material boost from a weakening dollar.
North America Economic Research United States 29 August 2025
Goods trade balance %bn, sa; Customs definition

Productivity and costsNovember business sector, %q/q, saar, unless notedRevPreRev1Q251Q252Q252Q25Productivity-0.8-1.82.43.0%oya1.41.21.31.4Output-0.3-0.63.74.4%oya2.22.12.32.5Hours0.61.21.31.3%oya0.80.91.01.0Hourly compensation4.85.04.04.1%oya2.73.23.94.0Unit labor costs5.76.91.61.0%oya1.32.02.62.5

We estimate that non- farm productivity growth in 2Q25 will have been revised up to \(3.0\%\) q/q saar from \(2.4\%\) in the initial release. The decline mostly reflects the downward revision to employment in the July report, which was not captured in the first print, leaving output moving up to \(4.4\% q/q\) from \(3.7\% q / q\) in the preliminary print. We expect real hourly compensation to change to \(4.1\%\) , resulting in unit labor costs declining \(1.0\%\) q/q, remaining the softest quarterly rise in ULC in three quarters.
Nonfarm business productivity
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan
Nonfarm business unit labor costs
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

We expect jobless claims to tick down to \(225k\) in the week ending August 30, from \(229k\) in the prior week, continuing to portray decent labor market growth through the month. Residual seasonality had driven initial claims to jump through early June and perhaps slightly during early August. The latest print was 4k below the corresponding week last year. This seasonal trend could also depress claims in the coming months.

Thu Sep 4 8:30amJobless claimsNew claims (wr.)Continuing claimsInsuredWkly4-wk avgWklyJun 212372451952Jun 282322411954Jul 52282361951Jul 12*2212301946Jul 192172251936Jul 262192211968Aug 22272211942Aug 92242221961Aug 16*2342261954Aug 23229229Aug 30225228
1. Payroll survey week

Continuing claims have been moving within a narrow range since late June. The latest reading was for the household reference week, with the count rising 8k from the July reference week. Continuing claims have been regularly revised down this year so the next report may show no change between the July and August reference weeks. The level of the series suggests an unemployment rate in the \(4.2\% - 4.3\%\) range.
Source: Department of Labor, J.P. Morgan
Jobless claims - 4 week average
Source: Department of Labor, J.P. Morgan

Thu Sep 4 9:45amS&P Global services PMI (US final)Index, saJul 24Jul 25Flash Aug 25Final Aug 25Business activity55.055.755.455.0New business53.054.154.7ThuISM servicesSep 4 10:00amSaHeadline compositeMayJunJulBusiness activity49.950.850.1New orders50.054.252.6Employment46.451.350.3Prices50.747.246.468.767.569.9

We look for the August ISM services index to rise to 51.0 from 50.1 in July, while the final PMI business activity measure experiences a slight downtick to 55.0 from the flash reading of 55.4. The latest PMI reading saw improvements in both the new business and new export orders indexes, which could signal strengthening services demand after a subdued start to the year, and the general business activity measure has been robust in the last two months. The ISM services composite, in contrast, has been deteriorating since October 2024, with the business activity, new orders, and employment indexes collectively weighing on demand.
The diverging signals between the ISM and PMI prints could partially result from differences in survey scope; the ISM sur

vey includes industries such as wholesale and retail trade, government, construction, mining, and agriculture, which are excluded from the PMI. However, a number of these industries were reported to be growing, so it's hard to conclude that the weaker ISM readings are linked to coverage differences.

Price inflation reported by services surveys remains elevated. The July ISM print recorded a \(\sim 1.5\) - point increase, while the more recent August flash PMI saw input prices moving sideways and output prices ticking up by close to one point from 58.2 in July. The employment measure has been one of the sources of diverging readings between the two surveys: the July ISM employment measure signaled a contraction in payrolls at 46.4, while the PMI counterpart reached 52.5 in the August flash reading, its highest level since the beginning of the year.
ISM services composite index
Service sector business activity measures
Source: S&P Global, ISM, J.P. Morgan

Fri Sep 5 8:30amLabor-market reportSaMayJunJulAugPayroll employment(ch, m/m, 000s)19147375Private payrolls6938375Goods-producing-13-13-13-5Construction2325Manufacturing-11-15-11-5Service-providing32278680Private service-providing82169680Wholesale trade2-8-8Retail trade-15-1416Professional services-23-11-14Temporary help-15-3-4Education/health705279Leisure and hospitality2745Government-5011-100Average weekly hours34.334.234.334.3Index, hrs worked (%/m/m)0.1-0.30.30.1Hourly earnings (%/m/m)0.40.20.30.3(%/ya)3.83.83.93.7Unemployment rate (%)4.24.14.24.3Participation rate (%)62.462.362.262.2

We expect nonfarm payrolls rose \(75k\) in August and that the unemployment rate increased from \(4.2\%\) to \(4.3\%\) . We also forecast that average hourly earnings rose \(0.3\% /m/m\) ( \(3.7\%\) oya) and that the workweek held at 34.3.

We forecast that both overall and private payrolls rose \(75k\) in August. We assume that federal government payrolls continue to steadily decline: excluding a large 26k cut in May, they've fallen by an average of \(12k\) per month since the start of the Trump administration, and we then expect this will be offset by growth in state and local employment. The administration has signalled that large additional federal layoffs are generally not needed in light of employment declines caused by attrition plus the \(\sim 150k\) employees who took deferred resignations and are set to roll off payrolls starting in October.
Change in nonfarm payroll employment 000s, m/m, sa
NFP growth, average over recent months (000s)
12 months6 months3 monthsTotal1288135Private1138552Federal govt-6-14-16S&amp;L govt2110-1Total ex federal govt1349551
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

For the private sector, job growth was 83k in July and aver-aged 52k per month over the past 3 months and 85k over the last 6 months. It's likely that breakeven employment has declined well under 100k given low net immigration. There is a possibility that the termination of temporary legal status for large numbers of immigrants, which we discussed recently here, could further depress payroll growth in the near term.However, it remains difficult to guess exactly how quickly these will hit the employment numbers.

Looking across a range of labor indicators there was not much change between July and August. The Conference Board's labor market differential kept falling, from 11.0% in July to 9.7% in August, but elsewhere there wasn't a clear trend. The PMI all-industry employment measure improved slightly, the regional Fed surveys were mostly unchanged,Indeed job openings ticked up, and the Census BTOS was better than a year earlier. Initial jobless claims rose 13k between the payroll reference weeks (the week including the 12th of the month), but the four-week average of claims fell.Continuing jobless claims rose just 8k, and since the latest week has tended to be revised down this year next week's claims report will likely show about no change over the month. In addition, employees working reported by Home-base have a fairly similar change over the month compared to the same month in prior years.

One additional observation comes from a speech this week by Governor Waller. He noted that weekly data that ADP shares with the Fed pointed to "continued deterioration" in the employment trend after the July survey week. That could also signal that the monthly ADP figure due out next week will be soft.

Revisions have been a hot topic ever since the large down-ward revisions that accompanied the July payroll report. Their magnitude was unusually large, but their direction was not, as revisions have been consistently negative over the last few years. Looking at past years, the August release was typically revised up, leading one to discount weakness in the first release, but this trend has reversed in the last few years, at least by the time of the third release. For the already-released July data there is not a clear pattern. In the last couple years there was a downward revision with the second release and a net upward revision by the time of the third release, but this may not be a new pattern. Finally, for the June data, revisions have been consistently negative since 2022. Normally,though, the big downward revisions come with the third
release, whereas this year there was already a large negative revision with the second release, so it is unclear if we are due for further revisions.
Revisions to August nonfarm payrolls
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan
Revisions to July nonfarm payrolls
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan
Revisions to June nonfarm payrolls
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

Average hourly earnings growth has been reasonably stable since 2024, and so we expect a \(0.3\% /m\) increase, which would represent a pace just a touch slower than the average in the year to July, when earnings rose \(3.9\%\) oya. The recent drop in employment growth could represent a softening labor market that would be consistent both with a slowing in wage growth and a reduction in the workweek, but slack, as captured in the unemployment rate, has not moved much to date.
Average hourly earnings growth
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

For the workweek, we look for no change at \(34.3. A drop to 34.2 is also possible given the week has fluctuated between 34.3 and 34.2 repeatedly since early last year. Recently the workweek in transportation and warehousing has increased, possibly linked to trade front- loading, and an eventual decline could put slight downward pressure on the overall workweek.
Average weekly hours
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

The unemployment rate was \(4.24\%\) in July, so it will take only a small increase to have it round up to \(4.3\%\) . The Conference Board consumer confidence survey's labor market differential kept worsening during August, falling from \(11.0\%\) to \(9.7\%\) . On the other hand, continuing jobless claims were roughly flat between the July and August household survey reference weeks. We also think a decline in unemployment among new labor market entrants could restrain any increase, which offers the possibility that the rate will remain at \(4.2\%\) .
Unemployment rate vs. continuing claims to labor force ratio Unemployment rate
Source: Department of Labor, BLS, J.P. Morgan. July assumes \(0.1\% m / m\) labor force rise
Unemployment rate vs. Conference Board labor market differential Unemployment rate
Source: BLS, Conference Board, J.P. Morgan

As seen in the figure below, there was a sharp rise in the number of unemployed new labor force entrants in July, with the \(39\% m / m\) rise being one of the largest percentage increases on record. As we discussed in a recent note, this is quite possibly sampling noise that will soon reverse. The data on unemployment by reason is seasonally adjusted separately and does not sum to the official change in the unemployment rate, which makes it challenging to estimate how much a reversal in this series would lower total unemployment. One possible approach is to note that when summing the unemployment data by reason, new entrants accounted for \(60\%\) of the increase. Given the overall unemployment rate rose \(13\) bps, a way of framing this is to estimate that new entrants accounted for \(60\%\) of that 13bps increase, or 8bps, and that a full reversal would cause the unemployment rate to fall by an equivalent amount.
Unemployed new labor force entrants
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

We also look for the participation rate to hold constant at \(62.2\%\) . The participation rate has been steadily falling since 2023. This has primarily reflected declines in participation for workers ages 16- 24 and \(55+\) . Along with the longer- run decline in youth participation there may be some residual seasonality in the last few years: since 2023 the rate has peaked in February and March each year, then declined into the summer, with troughs in July 2023 and August 2024. Were this pattern to repeat this year, it could contribute to a 20- 30bps increase in participation between now and early next year, holding participation constant for other age groups. In the short- term, though, it's possible that youth participation could edge down further in the August report, given the trough was in August last year.
Labor force participation rate
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan
Labor force participation rate: 16-24 year olds
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

Sources for all: ADP/Moody's Analytics, BEA, BLS, Census Bureau, Conference Board, Department of Labor, Federal Reserve Board, ISM, J.P. Morgan forecasts, NAHB, NAR, NFIB, NY Fed, Philadelphia Fed, S&P Global, Standard & Poor's, University of Michigan, US Treasury
New home sales (Aug 25)

New single- family home sales were 652k saar in July, down \(0.6\% \mathrm{mm}\) from an upwardly revised June level of 656k (previously 627k). Even with the upward revision, sales have had their softest three- month stretch since the start of 2024. The revisions plus the July data do provide a slightly more favorable looking trajectory for inventories, which were previously shown increasing to a cycle high in June. The current cycle high is now shown as occurring in March, with inventories largely flat since then (they are down \(1\%\) between March and July). Still, inventories and months' supply remain high, which should keep housing starts low for a time, given that the current pace of construction is not low enough to materially reduce inventory at the current sales pace. Pricing trends also remain weak, a similar message to that in the NAHB survey. The median price over the last three months is down \(2\%\) oya, as prices continue to gradually edge down from the 2022 high. Inflation- adjusted prices are now almost back in line with where they were at the end of 2019.
Durable goods (Aug 26) \(\% \mathrm{mm}\) sa
MayJunJulNew orders16.5-9.4-2.1Ex transportation0.60.20.0Nondef cap. gds ex air1.9-0.8-0.6Shipments0.30.50.0Ex transportation0.20.30.5Nondef cap. gds ex air0.40.30.4Inventories0.10.20.2

We view the July durable goods report as solid: total orders fell \(2.8\% \mathrm{mm}\) on an expected pullback in the volatile aircraft category, but core capital goods (nondefense ex aircraft) orders rose \(1.1\%\) and core capital goods shipments rose \(0.7\%\) while total shipments increased \(1.4\%\) . Both core capital goods orders and shipments have been trending up since late last year, with the nominal value of shipments exceeding the previous peak in 2023. The August flash manufacturing PMI suggests this strength could continue into this month, though other manufacturing surveys have been more mixed. Growth in nominal manufacturing inventories also continued, rising \(0.3\% \mathrm{mm}\) in July, compared to an average \(0.1\% \mathrm{mm}\) pace in the first half of the year. Some of this should reflect rising prices. However, the August flash PMI's diffusion index for stocks of finished goods also hit a record, and the equivalent measure for input materials was elevated, with the press release noting that firms were building inventories to protect against future supply disruptions and price pressures.
Consumer confidence (Aug 26)
SaJunJulAugConference Bd index95.297.298.797.0Present situation133.0131.5132.8131.2Jobs plentiful29.430.229.7Jobs hard to get17.218.918.920.0Labor mkt diff12.211.311.09.7Expectations69.974.476.074.8

The August Conference Board consumer confidence index was little changed from July, with the headline index edging down to 94.7 from 98.7 (revised from 97.2), with the present situation index falling to 131.2 from 132.8 and the expectations index to 74.8 from 76.0. However, the labor market differential continued to worsen, which along with continuing claims is pointing to the risk that the unemployment rounds up to \(4.3\%\) in the August employment report, from \(4.2\%\) in July ( \(4.24\%\) ). The differential was revised from \(11.3\%\) to \(11.0\%\) for July, then dipped to \(9.7\%\) in August. The differential has worsened every month this year, and so far there is no evidence that it is leveling off. Inflation expectations reversed some of the reduction they've seen since April, mirroring what happened in the preliminary August University of Michigan sentiment survey. Median one- year expectations rose from \(4.7\%\) to \(5.1\%\) . They had recently peaked at \(5.9\%\) after the Liberation Day tariffs were announced, then fallen steadily through July. Consistent with this, write- in responses to the survey had more mentions of tariffs, as well as high prices generally.
Gross domestic product (Aug 28) %ch, q/q, saar, real, unless noted

1Q25Adv 2025Sec 2Q25Real GDP-0.53.03.2(%ya)2.02.02.0Final Sales-3.16.36.5(%ya)1.32.42.5Domestic final sales1.51.11.6(%ya)2.72.32.4Net exports (pct.pct.cont.)-4.65.04.9Inventories (pct.pct.cont.)2.6-3.2-3.3Consumption0.51.41.8Equipment23.74.85.4Intellectual property6.06.48.5Nons. structures-2.4-10.3-8.6Residential investment-1.3-4.6-5.0Government-0.60.40.7Exports0.4-1.8-1.8Imports38.0-30.3-30.3Net exports (Bbn)-1359.0-1026.3-1031.4Inventories (ch, Bbn)160.5-26.0-33.9Nominal GDP3.25.05.1(%ya)4.74.54.6GDP chain price index3.82.02.0(%ya)2.62.5PCE price index0.51.41.6(%ya)2.52.42.4Core PCE price index3.52.52.5(%ya)2.82.7Corporate profits (%q/q, sa)-2.30.0-2.3(%ya)6.30.09.6Employee compensation5.45.15.0(%ya)4.44.84.8Wages and salaries5.24.94.8(%ya)4.24.74.7

The second release of 2Q real GDP saw growth revised up from \(3.0\% \mathrm{q} / \mathrm{q}\) saar to \(3.3\%\) , which reflected upward revisions to consumption ( \(1.4\%\) to \(1.6\%\) ), as well as nonresidential business fixed investment ( \(1.9\%\) to \(5.7\%\) ). Within nonresidential business investment every category was revised up, especially IPP ( \(6.4\%\) to \(12.8\%\) ) and equipment ( \(4.8\%\) to \(7.4\%\) ). IPP had been notably weak last year, rising just \(2.7\%\) , but has since risen \(9.3\%\) annualized in the first half of this year. That can principally be attributed to a \(22\%\) rise in software spending, which likely in part reflects some of the new revenue tech firms are earning from selling AI software services. Software sales are estimated with a judgmental trend in the first release of GDP, but begin to be based on hard data from the Quarterly Services Survey in the second release. This report also included the first look at GDI, which rose \(4.8\% \mathrm{q} / \mathrm{q}\) saar in real terms, outperforming GDP. The notable thing here was that pre- tax corporate profits rebounded in 2Q despite the rise in tariff charges (pre- tax profits exclude income taxes but are inclusive of tariff costs). Nominal profits rose \(1.7\% \mathrm{q} / \mathrm{q}\) (not annualized), rebounding from a \(2.3\%\) fall the prior quarter. Over year ago they increased \(4.3\%\) , which is a deceleration from the \(10.8\%\) pace in the prior year.

Pending home sales, which lead existing home sales by 1- 2 months, declined \(0.4\% \mathrm{m / m}\) in July and are up just \(0.3\% \mathrm{ya}\) . There continues to be very little movement in the existing home sales market, with sales stuck at low levels since 2023. There may be a bit of improvement in August given a small decline in mortgage rates, which as early this week were at their lowest level since early April, although the absolute level of rates remains quite high.
Personal income (Aug 29)

MayJunJulPersonal income-0.4-0.40.3Wages &amp; salaries0.30.10.6Disposable personal income-0.5-0.50.3Real disposable personal income-0.7-0.70.0Consumption0.00.00.3Real consumption-0.2-0.20.1PCE price index0.20.20.3Core0.20.30.3Mkt-Based Core0.20.20.3Core (%ya)2.82.82.9Mkt-Based Core (%ya)2.42.62.6Saving rate4.54.54.4

The core PCE deflator rose \(0.27\% \mathrm{m / m}\) ( \(2.88\% \mathrm{ya}\) ) in July, a number that should keep the Fed concerned about upside inflation pressures, though not enough to stop them from cutting in September to stem downside labor market risks. The over- year- ago rate is up from a recent low of \(2.6\%\) in April, though remains within the range it has been in since the start of last year. The failure to make further progress toward the \(2\%\) inflation target was recognized in the July FOMC minutes, though in a speech this week Governor Waller was more sanguine. In particular, he said that excluding tariffs, which he expects will be a one- off price shift, "underlying inflation continues to run close to the FOMC's 2 percent target." That conclusion is based on work by Minton and Somale (2025) to estimate the real- time contribution of tariffs to inflation. The core services ex housing supercore metric meanwhile rose a firm \(0.4\% \mathrm{m / m}\) , the most since February, and was up \(3.3\% \mathrm{ya}\) , with that over- year- ago rate a tick higher than it was in the prior 12- month period.

On the spending side, real consumption increased \(0.3\% \mathrm{m / m}\) , the best rise since March, supported by an increase in motor vehicle spending. Our equity analysts expect only a \(1\%\) drop in unit auto sales for August, implying a limited drag from the volatile segment on spending in August. If spending were to grow just \(0.1\% \mathrm{m / m}\) in August and September then 3Q would

be up \(1.7\% \mathrm{q / q}\) saar. Over the last year spending rose \(0.17\% \mathrm{m / m}\) on average, and while rising inflation could dampen real spending, we are upgrading our 2Q consumption from \(1.5\%\) to \(2.0\%\) .

The labor income data was also constructive, as real wages rose \(0.4\% \mathrm{m / m}\) , while real disposable personal income increased a smaller \(0.2\%\) , and the saving rate held stable at \(4.4\%\) . On a \(3\mathrm {m}/3\mathrm {m}\) basis real wage income rose \(2.3\%\) saar. By comparison, nonfarm payroll employment rose just \(0.5\%\) in the same period, highlighting that while job growth has slowed, income has held up better. Real DPI on a \(3\mathrm {m}/3\mathrm {m}\) basis rose just \(0.2\%\) , but this is being depressed by recent swings in Social Security income, with that segment having been temporarily boosted earlier in the year as retroactive payments were made under the Social Security Fairness Act.
International trade (adv.) (Aug 29)
\$bn, samr, unless noted
Balance of goods, Cen. BasisMayJunJulExports (%samr)-96.2-84.9-86.6 -103.6Imports (%samr)-5.6-0.70.2 -0.1-0.1-4.60.8 7.1
Business inventories (adv.) (Aug 29)
%m/m, sa, unless noted
MayJunJulWholesale-0.30.1 0.10.2 0.2Retail inventories0.20.2 0.20.3 0.2Ex autos0.1-0.10.2 0.1Autos0.61.0 0.80.4

The nominal trade deficit widened substantially, rising from $84.9bn in June to $103.6bn as exports fell \(0.1\% \mathrm {m}/\mathrm {m}\) and imports surged \(7.1\%\) . The import rise was led by a \(25\%\) gain in industrial supply imports. It's possible there was some con-tribution here from renewed gold imports, which don't affect GDP, though imports ex industrial supplies were also up \(2.9\%\) . A simple calculation of the change in COMEX ware-house gold inventories times average prices shows a $5bn rise, which would be only part of the $12bn increase in indus-trial supply imports. There could also be front-loading of cop-per imports ahead of the August 1 implementation of the \(50\%\) tariffs. In theory those should show up in inventories, though the \(0.2\% \mathrm {m}/\mathrm {m}\) ($5.6bn) rise in total manufacturing and trade inventories didn't look unusually strong.
Consumer sentiment (Aug 29)
JulPreAugFinAugUniv. of Mich. Index (nsa)61.758.659.0 58.2Current conditions68.060.961.7Expectations57.757.255.9Inflation expectationsShort term4.54.94.8Long term3.43.93.5
The August Michigan sentiment survey edged down to 58.2 in the final release from 58.6 in the preliminary, and is down slightly from 61.7 in July: sentiment remains soft despite hav-

ing recovered 11% from the recent April/May lows. The most notable change between the preliminary and final releases was the August rebound in inflation expectations now doesn't look as large, especially long-term expectations. The 5-10 inflation expectation measure was 3.4% in July, rose to 3.9% in the preliminary release, and then fell back to 3.5% in the final. One-year inflation expectations went from 4.5% to 4.9% in the preliminary and are now 4.8%. The press release noted that the survey period ended the day President Trump announced he was firing Fed Governor Lisa Cook, so that development shouldn't have had much impact. The press release also noted that Democratic inflation expectations had been stable between July and August, with the rise coming from Republicans and independents.
